conclusion: Consider principles of shadow formation and geometry of objects.
Light source casts shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
Shadows are elongated in the direction opposite to the light source.
Moving light source to back left shifts shadows towards front right.
Shadows become larger if light source moves closer due to more oblique angle.
Shadows become smaller if light source moves further away.
Moving light source to back right shifts shadows towards front left.
Shadows become larger if light source moves closer.
Shadows become smaller if light source moves further away.
Shadow A stretches more in new direction when light moves to back left or right.
Shadow B elongates more in direction opposite to new light position.
Shadow C shifts and possibly becomes more elongated depending on light's new position.
Shadow D shifts and may elongate based on new light direction.
When light source moves to back left, shadows shift towards front right and change size based on distance.
When light source moves to back right, shadows shift towards front left and change size based on distance.
Primary changes are in direction and potentially size of shadows depending on light source distance.
